full_text: The purpose of this demonstration is to test how BillingCenter handles a cancellation. In this demo, we'll use the same policy that I used in the previous demo to show policy change processing. However, I need to be logged in as SuperUser to run a debug command. Let's start by going to the policyholders account. I click the invoices link in the sidebar. On the invoices screen, in the do column, there is a total of $540 remaining to be paid on the policy. This is the amount we'll specify on the debug command to cancel the policy. I click the policy link to return to the policy summary screen. Notice the current cancellation status is open. I click in the quick jump box to enter the cancel command. The command is, run policy cancel this minus 540. I press return to execute the command. I press return to execute the command. Immediately, we see the cancellation status has changed from open to canceled. Let's take a look at the charges for the policy. A new cancellation charge has been added in the amount that I specified on the run command. Let's return to the account summary screen. In the policy period section, we can see today's date has been entered in the cancellation date field for the policy. Next, I'll go to the invoices screen. Notice there are only two invoices, the original due invoice and one planned invoice. The planned invoice is the future invoice that resulted from the cancellation. I'll click the plan invoice. As we see, all invoice items from the original planned invoices have been moved to this invoice. Let's switch the sort to group by installment number. Now let's look at the charges. The cancellation charge is already selected. Notice the negative $540 was sliced into a down payment, and three installments according to the payment plan. Does it matter how the charge was sliced? No, for a cancellation, all unsettled invoice items end up on the same invoice, so charge slicing does not matter. This concludes our demo on testing cancellation processing.

segments.text: The purpose of this demonstration is to test how BillingCenter handles a cancellation. In this demo, we'll use the same policy that I used in the previous demo to show policy change processing. However, I need to be logged in as SuperUser to run a debug command. Let's start by going to the policyholders account. I click the invoices link in the sidebar. On the invoices screen, in the do column, there is a total of $540

remaining to be paid on the policy. This is the amount we'll specify on the debug command to cancel the policy. I click the policy link to return to the policy summary screen. Notice the current cancellation status is open. I click in the quick jump box to enter the cancel command. The command is, run policy cancel this minus 540.

I press return to execute the command. I press return to execute the command. Immediately, we see the cancellation status has changed from open to canceled. Let's take a look at the charges for the policy. A new cancellation charge has been added in the amount that I specified on the run command. Let's return to the account summary screen.
In the policy period section, we can see today's date has been entered in the cancellation date field for the policy. Next, I'll go to the invoices screen.
Notice there are only two invoices, the original due invoice and one planned invoice. The planned invoice is the future invoice that resulted from the cancellation. I'll click the plan invoice.
As we see, all invoice items from the original planned invoices have been moved to this invoice. Let's switch the sort to group by installment number.
Now let's look at the charges.
The cancellation charge is already selected. Notice the negative $540 was sliced into a down payment, and three installments according to the payment plan.
Does it matter how the charge was sliced? No, for a cancellation, all unsettled invoice items end up on the same invoice, so charge slicing does not matter.
This concludes our demo on testing cancellation processing.
